Subject: Business Management
ContentDescription: Businesses of all sizes are major contributors to the economic and social wellbeing of a nation. The ability of entrepreneurs to establish a business and the fostering of conditions under which new business ideas can emerge are vital for a nation's wellbeing. Taking a business idea and planning how to make it a reality are the cornerstones of economic and social development. In this unit students explore the factors affecting business ideas and the internal and external environments within which businesses operate, as well as the effect of these on planning a business. They also consider the importance of the business sector to the national economy and social wellbeing.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
ContentDescription: In this area of study students investigate the concept of entrepreneurship.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
Elaboration: They consider how business ideas are created and how conditions can be fostered for new business ideas to emerge.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
Elaboration: New business ideas come from a range of sources, such as identifying a gap in the market, technological developments and changing customer needs.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
Elaboration: Students explore some of the considerations to be made before a business can be established as well as the importance of businesses to the national economy and social wellbeing.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to describe a process for creating and developing 
a business idea, and explain how innovative and entrepreneurial practices can contribute to the national economy and social wellbeing.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The business idea
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Internal business environment and planning
ContentDescription: The internal environment affects the approach a business takes to planning and the extent to which planning is successful.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Internal business environment and planning
Elaboration: A business owner will generally have more control over the activities, functions and pressures that occur within the business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Internal business environment and planning
Elaboration: These factors, such as business models, legal business structures and staffing, will also be influenced to some extent by the external environment.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Internal business environment and planning
Elaboration: Students explore the factors within the internal business environment and consider how planning decisions involving these factors may affect the ultimate success of a business, with success being measured by the extent to which business objectives are met within a specific timeframe.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Internal business environment and planning
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to describe the internal business environment and analyse how factors from within it may affect business planning.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
ContentDescription: The external environment consists of all elements outside a business that may act as pressures or forces on business operations.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
Elaboration: Students consider factors from the external environment such as legal, political, social, economic, technological, global and corporate social responsibility factors and the effects these may have on the decisions made when planning a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to describe the external environment of a business and explain how the macro and operating factors within it may affect business planning.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

ContentDescription: a case study analysis

Subject: Business Management

ContentDescription: a business research report

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
ContentDescription: development of a business plan and/or feasibility study

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning
ContentDescription: an interview with and a report on a chosen business

ContentDescription: a school-based, short-term business activity

ContentDescription: an essay

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - External business environment and planning

Subject: Business Management
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on the establishment phase of a business. Establishing a business involves compliance with legal requirements as well as decisions about how best to establish a system of financial record keeping, staff the business and establish a customer base. In this unit students examine the legal requirements that must be met to establish a business. They investigate the essential features of effective marketing and consider the best way to meet the needs of the business in terms of staffing and financial record keeping. Students analyse management practices by applying key knowledge to contemporary business case studies from the past four years.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Legal requirements and financial considerations
ContentDescription: It is essential to deal with legal and financial matters when establishing a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Legal requirements and financial considerations
Elaboration: In this area of study students are introduced to the legal requirements and financial considerations that are vital in establishing a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Legal requirements and financial considerations
Elaboration: They also consider the implications for the business if legal and financial requirements are not met.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Legal requirements and financial considerations
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to outline the key legal requirements and financial record-keeping considerations when establishing a business, and explain the importance of establishing effective policies and procedures to achieve compliance with these requirements.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Legal requirements and financial considerations
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Marketing a business
ContentDescription: Establishing a strong customer base for a business is an important component of success.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Marketing a business
Elaboration:
In this area 
of study students develop an understanding that marketing encompasses a wide range of management practices, from identifying the needs of the target market and creating a brand presence through to consideration of the 7Ps of marketing and the impact of rapidly changing technology on marketing practices.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Marketing a business
Elaboration:
They also consider effective public relations strategies and the benefits these can bring to 
a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Marketing a business
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain how establishing a customer base and 
a marketing presence supports the achievement of business objectives, analyse effective marketing and public relations strategies and apply these strategies to business-related case studies.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Marketing a business
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
ContentDescription: Staff, as one of the greatest assets of a business, are an important consideration during the establishment phase.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
Elaboration: The quantity and quality of staff has a direct link to business productivity and the achievement of business objectives.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
Elaboration: In this area of study students consider staffing requirements that will meet the needs of a business and contribute to productivity and achievement of business objectives.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
Elaboration: They research the processes undertaken by the business in relation to the recruitment, selection and induction of staff.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
Elaboration: Students consider the opportunities that the skills and capabilities of staff can offer a business, the legal obligations that must be addressed in relation to staff, and the relationship between employers and employees within a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the importance of staff to a business, discuss the staffing needs for a business, and evaluate staff-management strategies from both an employer and staff perspective.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Staffing a business
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Business Management
ContentDescription:
In this unit students explore the key processes and considerations for managing a business efficiently
and effectively to achieve business objectives. Students examine different types of businesses and their respective objectives and stakeholders. They investigate strategies to manage both staff and business operations to meet objectives, and develop an understanding of the complexity and challenge of managing businesses. Students compare theoretical perspectives with current practice through the use of contemporary Australian and global business case studies from the past four years.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Business foundations
ContentDescription: This area of study introduces students to the key characteristics of businesses and their stakeholders.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Business foundations
Elaboration: Students investigate potential conflicts between the different demands of stakeholders on a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Business foundations
Elaboration: They examine corporate culture and a range of management styles and management skills that may be used when managing a business, and apply these to contemporary business case studies from the past four years.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Business foundations
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the key characteristics of businesses, their stakeholders, management styles and skills, and corporate culture.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Business foundations
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
ContentDescription: In this area of study students investigate considerations for the effective management of employees to ensure business objectives are achieved.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
Elaboration: They consider employee motivation in terms of Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, Locke and Latham’s Goal Setting Theory, and Lawrence and Nohria’s Four Drive Theory.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
Elaboration: Using these theories of motivation and motivation strategies, students propose and justify possible strategies for employee management in contemporary business case studies from the past four years.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
Elaboration: Students study an overview of workplace relations, including the main participants and their roles in the dispute resolution process.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain theories of motivation and apply them to
a range of contexts, and analyse and evaluate strategies related to the management of employees.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Human resource management
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Operations management
ContentDescription: The production of goods and services is a core objective of businesses.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Operations management
Elaboration: Effective management of the process of transforming inputs into outputs is vital to the success of a business, both in terms of maximising the efficiency and effectiveness of the production process and meeting the needs of stakeholders.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Operations management
Elaboration:
In this area of study students examine operations management and consider the best and most responsible use 
of available resources to produce a quality final good or service in a competitive, global environment.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Operations management
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the relationship between business objectives and operations management, and propose and evaluate strategies to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of business operations.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Operations management
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Business Management
ContentDescription: Businesses are under constant pressure to adapt and change to meet their objectives. In this unit students consider the importance of reviewing key performance indicators to determine current performance and the strategic management necessary to position a business for the future. Students study a theoretical model to undertake change and consider a variety of strategies to manage change in the most efficient and effective way to improve business performance. They investigate the importance of effective management and leadership in change management. Using one or more contemporary business case studies from the past four years, students evaluate business practice against theory.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentDescription: In this area of study students develop their understanding of the need for change.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
Elaboration: Managers regularly review and evaluate business performance through use of key performance indicators and use the results to make decisions affecting the future of a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
Elaboration: Managers can take both a proactive and reactive approach to change.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
Elaboration:
Students investigate the ways a business can search for new business opportunities as a source 
of future business growth and consider current forces for change on a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
Elaboration: They apply Lewin’s Force Field Analysis theory to contemporary case studies from the past four years and consider approaches to strategic management using Porter’s Generic Strategies.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain the way business change may come about, analyse why managers may take a proactive or reactive approach to change, use key performance indicators to analyse the performance of a business, explain the driving and restraining forces for change, and evaluate management strategies to position a business for the future.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentHeader: Reviewing performance – the need for change
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: In this area of study students explore how businesses respond to evaluation data.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: It is important for managers to know where they want a business to be positioned for the future before implementing a variety of strategies to bring about the desired change.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: Students consider the importance of leadership in change management and discuss and evaluate effective strategies for managing change.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: Students consider how leaders can inspire change and the effect change can have on stakeholders of a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: They consider the principles of Senge’s Learning Organisation and apply the Three-step Change Model (Lewin) in implementing change in a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: Using one or more contemporary business case studies from the past four years, students evaluate business practice against theory, considering how corporate social responsibility can be incorporated into the change process.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the importance of effective management strategies and leadership in relation to change, evaluate the effectiveness of a variety of strategies used by managers to implement change, and discuss the effect of change on the stakeholders of a business.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: All the key knowledge and key skills that underpin the outcomes in Units 3 and 4 are examinable.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: Duration: 2 hours.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: Date: end-of-year, on a date to be published annually by the VCAA.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: VCAA examination rules will apply.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
Elaboration: Details of these rules are published annually in the VCE Administrative Handbook.

Subject: Business Management
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Implementing change
ContentDescription: The examination will be marked by assessors appointed by the VCAA.
